text: there used to be a front door here and I
had walk away then I had decks going all
the way down here while he was in Iraq
trying to help the US win a war James
Hurley learned that back home in
Michigan he was losing his house today
he walks around the property that used
to belong to him with a mixture of
nostalgia and anger everything right
there I've I put on this is mark
scheffler for the New York Times
Hurley's old house is on a wooded two
and a half acre location overlooking a
river near the small town of Hartford
Michigan it's the first time he is set
foot here since 2004 just before he was
deployed to Iraq while he was serving
overseas he knew he was falling behind
on his payments but he thought he was
protected when he returned home over a
year later he found that his house had
not only been foreclosed on it had also
been resold to someone else I wish it
was all still nine it was mine at the
time I left they shouldn't never took it
it should still be mine today a judge
has already ruled that the foreclosure
by deutsche bank and an entity called
saxon mortgage services was illegal
under a law called the Servicemembers
Civil Relief Act or scra which protects
military personnel from foreclosures now
Hurley and his attorney Matt Cooper are
awaiting their day in court they're
seeking damages that Deutsche Bank says
it isn't obligated to pay the scra says
those damages are available and why
wouldn't they be the scra was drafted by
Congress to protect our men and women in
the military hurley now lives in another
house several miles away he says that
his credit score was damaged by the
foreclosure and that the stress of the
eviction affected his marriage his wife
is currently living in Texas if I leave
my regular hold I should come home to my
regular home not to a place that's three
times smaller just a majestic river
running through it well throw a bank and
Saxon have stated in legal documents
that James Hurley is entitled to no more
than the fair market value of his house
or about seventy six thousand dollars
but Matt Cooper argues that compensation
should go well beyond that he's lost
everything his home all his possessions
his wife the two girls he was gonna
adopt what is he lost he's lost
everything Cooper and Hurley will argue
their case before a jury in March
meanwhile Hurley says he's still trying
to get his life back in order he has
medical issues stemming from his tour of
duty in Iraq where he served as a
mechanic with the Michigan National
Guard he's currently unemployed and says
finding a job is tough with his
disabilities you got people with a lot a
lot of money up here and you got
somebody down here that's barely making
money to pay what they want and they're
like ah we can swash you and your
they're trying to squash me and his old
house seems out of reach at this point
the current owners say they don't want
to sell but that doesn't mean Hurley has
stopped thinking about it it's kind of
like a nightmare it's just I ain't woke
up yet because I still think about the
other place I still drive by it and it
to my point of view it ain't right
